title: Isaiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 22 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 22.

questions.question: What is described as 'the burden of the valley of vision' in Isaiah 22:1?
options: The city of Jerusalem
The valley of Hinnom
The mountain of Zion
The desert of Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: The city of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:1 refers to the burden of the valley of vision, which is commonly understood as a reference to Jerusalem.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 22:2, how were the slain men in the city killed?
options: Not with the sword nor in battle
By famine
By the sword in battle
By disease
questions.correctAnswer: Not with the sword nor in battle
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:2 states the slain men were not killed with the sword, nor dead in battle.

questions.question: Who are said to have fled and been bound by archers in Isaiah 22:3?
options: All the rulers
The priests
The prophets
The merchants
questions.correctAnswer: All the rulers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:3 mentions that all the rulers fled and were bound by the archers.

questions.question: What does the speaker in Isaiah 22:4 say he will do because of the spoiling of the daughter of his people?
options: Weep bitterly
Rejoice
Pray silently
Celebrate
questions.correctAnswer: Weep bitterly
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:4 shows the speaker will weep bitterly and asks others not to comfort him.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 22:5 describe as happening in the valley of vision?
options: Trouble, treading down, and perplexity
Peace and prosperity
A great feast
A mighty flood
questions.correctAnswer: Trouble, treading down, and perplexity
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:5 describes a day of trouble, treading down, and perplexity by the Lord in the valley of vision.

questions.question: Which two nations are mentioned in Isaiah 22:6 as bearing chariots and uncovering shields?
options: Elam and Kir
Babylon and Egypt
Assyria and Philistia
Moab and Ammon
questions.correctAnswer: Elam and Kir
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:6 mentions Elam carrying the quiver with chariots and Kir uncovering the shield.

questions.question: What did the people do to the houses of Jerusalem according to Isaiah 22:10?
options: Broke them down to fortify the wall
Painted them with bright colors
Left them untouched
Converted them into temples
questions.correctAnswer: Broke them down to fortify the wall
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:10 states that the houses of Jerusalem were broken down to fortify the wall.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 22:11, what did the people fail to look unto?
options: The maker and former of the pools
The king of Judah
The leaders of the city
The coming enemy
questions.correctAnswer: The maker and former of the pools
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:11 explains that while they made a ditch for water, they did not look to the maker who fashioned it.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 22:12 describes the Lord calling to weeping, mourning, baldness, and girding with sackcloth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:12 states that the Lord called to these expressions of mourning.

questions.question: What attitude do the people express in Isaiah 22:13 despite the trouble they face?
options: Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we die
Let us fast and pray for mercy
Let us prepare for battle
Let us flee from the city
questions.correctAnswer: Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we die
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:13 quotes the people saying 'Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we shall die,' showing a careless attitude.

questions.question: Who is the treasurer addressed by the Lord GOD of hosts in Isaiah 22:15?
options: Shebna
Eliakim
Hilkiah
Elam
questions.correctAnswer: Shebna
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:15 commands to go to Shebna, the treasurer over the house.

questions.question: What was Shebna accused of doing in Isaiah 22:16?
options: Hewing himself out a sepulchre on high
Leading an army against Jerusalem
Ignoring the prophet's warnings
Building a tower in the city
questions.correctAnswer: Hewing himself out a sepulchre on high
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:16 criticizes Shebna for hewing a tomb for himself on high, showing pride and self-interest.

questions.question: What will happen to Shebna according to Isaiah 22:17?
options: The LORD will carry him away with a mighty captivity
He will become king
He will be honored by the people
He will die peacefully in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will carry him away with a mighty captivity
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:17 declares that Shebna will be carried away captive by the Lord.

questions.question: Who will replace Shebna according to Isaiah 22:20?
options: Eliakim the son of Hilkiah
Elam the warrior
Kir the shield bearer
Hilkiah the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim the son of Hilkiah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:20 states that Eliakim son of Hilkiah will be called to replace Shebna.

questions.question: True or False: In Isaiah 22:22, Eliakim is given the key of the house of David, enabling him to open and shut as he pleases.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:22 describes Eliakim being given the key of the house of David with authority to open and shut.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 22 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is overwhelmed by trouble and perplexity. Based on Isaiah 22, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in such times?
options: God allows troubles to refine our faith and calls us to seek Him rather than rely on our own efforts
Troubles mean God has abandoned us and we should give up
We should only rely on human strength and ignore God during hardships
Perplexity is a sign of weakness and lack of faith
questions.correctAnswer: God allows troubles to refine our faith and calls us to seek Him rather than rely on our own efforts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:5 speaks of a day of trouble and perplexity by the LORD of hosts. Verses 9-11 show the people focused on physical defenses but neglected the Maker. This teaches us to trust God rather than solely our own efforts in trials.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 22 teach humility and reliance on God rather than on human achievements?
options: By showing that the people fortified walls and gathered water but did not look to God who made them
By praising the city's strong walls and human wisdom
By encouraging self-reliance in times of danger
By advising to hide from enemies rather than face them
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that the people fortified walls and gathered water but did not look to God who made them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:9-11 describes how the people focused on physical preparations but failed to look to the Maker and former Creator. This highlights the need for humility and dependence on God’s provision.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to give up because of sorrow and loss. Based on Isaiah 22:4-6, what encouragement about mourning and prayer can you offer?
options: It is appropriate to weep and call out to God in times of sorrow, recognizing His sovereignty
Mourning is useless and should be avoided
We should hide our sorrow and pretend all is well
Sorrow means God is angry and we should stop praying
questions.correctAnswer: It is appropriate to weep and call out to God in times of sorrow, recognizing His sovereignty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:4 shows the prophet weeping bitterly, and verse 5 describes crying to the mountains. This teaches that expressing sorrow and praying to God in distress is right and acknowledges His control.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 22 teach about leadership and stewardship in the church or family context?
options: God appoints faithful servants to lead and care for His people, as seen in Eliakim’s role
Leaders should seek personal glory above all else
Leadership is only about power and control, not service
Leadership should be avoided to prevent responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: God appoints faithful servants to lead and care for His people, as seen in Eliakim’s role
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:20-23 describes God appointing Eliakim and giving him authority and responsibility over the house of David. This shows leadership as a stewardship entrusted by God for care and guidance.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 22:12-13, how does the passage warn against a worldly attitude in difficult times?
options: It warns against responding to calamity with careless joy and ignoring the gravity of sin
It encourages celebrating without worry in all circumstances
It teaches that sorrow should be replaced by immediate happiness
It says faith means avoiding any sadness
questions.correctAnswer: It warns against responding to calamity with careless joy and ignoring the gravity of sin
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:12-13 contrasts the Lord’s call to mourning with the people’s response of joy and drinking ‘for tomorrow we die.’ This warns against flippant or worldly attitudes in the face of judgment.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 22 emphasize the importance of honoring God’s design and provision in our daily work and stewardship?
options: By rebuking the people for not considering the maker of the water supply while making defenses
By encouraging them to rely only on human innovation
By promoting pride in human accomplishments over God’s
By focusing solely on military strength as the source of security
questions.correctAnswer: By rebuking the people for not considering the maker of the water supply while making defenses
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:11 points out that the people made a ditch for the water but did not look to God who made it. This teaches the value of honoring God’s provision in all areas of life and work.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with pride and self-reliance. What biblical truth from Isaiah 22:15-19 would you share about God’s judgment on prideful leaders?
options: God will remove and disgrace leaders who exalt themselves and do not trust Him
Prideful leaders are always blessed and protected
Leaders should prioritize their own glory above others
God ignores the pride of leaders
questions.correctAnswer: God will remove and disgrace leaders who exalt themselves and do not trust Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:15-19 describes Shebna’s pride in making a tomb for himself and God’s judgment removing him from office. This warns against pride and self-exaltation in leadership.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 22:21-23 teach us about God’s sovereignty in appointing leaders who serve with integrity?
options: God clothes and strengthens His chosen servant to govern faithfully and open or shut as He wills
Leaders succeed only by their own strength and wisdom
God leaves leadership to chance without involvement
Leadership is based on popularity, not God’s choice
questions.correctAnswer: God clothes and strengthens His chosen servant to govern faithfully and open or shut as He wills
questions.explanation: Verses Isaiah 22:21-23 show God clothing Eliakim with authority and the key of the house of David, symbolizing divine appointment and sovereign control over leadership.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 22 teaches that in times of crisis, people should focus primarily on physical defenses and ignore spiritual dependence on God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:9-11 shows the people focusing on physical defenses but neglecting to look to the Maker of those provisions, which is rebuked. The chapter teaches reliance on God over mere human effort.

questions.question: True or False: The chapter encourages rejoicing and celebrating without concern for sin or judgment during times of trouble.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:12-14 contrasts God’s call to mourning with the people’s careless joy, and God declares their iniquity will not be purged. The chapter warns against ignoring sin and judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 22 teaches that God will ___ His servant Eliakim and make him a strong leader for Jerusalem.
options: clothe
ignore
reject
punish
questions.correctAnswer: clothe
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:21 states that God will clothe Eliakim with the robe and strengthen him with the girdle, symbolizing his appointment and empowerment as a leader.

questions.question: How should a Christian view leadership responsibilities based on the example of Eliakim in Isaiah 22:20-24?
options: As a sacred trust from God requiring faithfulness and care for others
As an opportunity for personal gain and pride
As a burden to avoid at all costs
As a role to be taken lightly and casually
questions.correctAnswer: As a sacred trust from God requiring faithfulness and care for others
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:20-24 shows Eliakim entrusted with the government, described as a father to the inhabitants, emphasizing leadership as service and responsibility.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to trust in human strength alone during trials. What does Isaiah 22:5-7 teach about true security?
options: True security comes from trusting God, not just military strength or human defenses
Security is guaranteed by horses and chariots alone
One should rely on their own planning without God's help
Security is impossible and should not be sought
questions.correctAnswer: True security comes from trusting God, not just military strength or human defenses
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:5-7 describes military preparations but the overall context condemns reliance on human means without God. True security depends on God’s protection.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 22:14, what is the consequence of ignoring God’s call to repentance and mourning?
options: Iniquity will remain until death and not be purged
God will immediately forgive without repentance
Ignoring God has no consequences
God rewards stubbornness
questions.correctAnswer: Iniquity will remain until death and not be purged
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:14 states that the iniquity will not be purged until death, showing the serious consequence of refusing God’s call to repentance.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 22 illustrate the importance of spiritual discipline like mourning and humility in God's service?
options: God calls for weeping, mourning, and humility rather than reckless joy in judgment
God prefers people to ignore sorrow and always be joyful
Spiritual discipline is optional and unnecessary
Joy and gladness are always the right response, even in sin
questions.correctAnswer: God calls for weeping, mourning, and humility rather than reckless joy in judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:12-13 contrasts God’s call to mourning with the people’s joy. This teaches the necessity of humility and spiritual discipline in responding to God’s judgment.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 22.

questions.question: What is the 'valley of vision' as described in Isaiah 22:1, and how does it symbolically relate to Jerusalem?
options: A prophetic term for Jerusalem representing a place of revelation
A literal valley famous for its strategic military importance
A metaphor for the wilderness where the Israelites wandered
An ancient name for the region of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: A prophetic term for Jerusalem representing a place of revelation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:1 calls the burden 'the valley of vision,' which scholars interpret as a symbolic reference to Jerusalem, known for divine revelations and prophetic visions.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 22:2, what is unusual about the slain men in the city?
options: They were not killed by the sword nor died in battle
They died from famine and disease
They were slain by foreign invaders with arrows
They were victims of an earthquake
questions.correctAnswer: They were not killed by the sword nor died in battle
questions.explanation: Verse 2 explicitly states the slain were not killed by the sword or in battle, indicating an unusual cause of death, perhaps internal chaos or disaster.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Isaiah 22:3 when describing rulers bound by archers and those who fled being captured?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Metaphor
Alliteration
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:3 uses parallelism by contrasting rulers fleeing and being captured, emphasizing total collapse of leadership.

questions.question: In Isaiah 22:4, the speaker says, 'Look away from me; I will weep bitterly.' This emotional appeal is an example of which prophetic technique?
options: Lamentation
Narrative prophecy
Apocalyptic imagery
Legal indictment
questions.correctAnswer: Lamentation
questions.explanation: The verse expresses deep sorrow and mourning over the people's suffering, characteristic of lamentation in prophetic literature.

questions.question: Which nations are mentioned as bearing quivers and chariots in Isaiah 22:6, and what is their role historically?
options: Elam and Kir, representing hostile foreign powers threatening Judah
Egypt and Babylon, allies of Israel
Moab and Ammon, neighboring peaceful tribes
Assyria and Philistia, trading partners
questions.correctAnswer: Elam and Kir, representing hostile foreign powers threatening Judah
questions.explanation: Verse 6 names Elam and Kir, ancient enemies who symbolize external threats in the geopolitical context of the Near East.

questions.question: What does the 'covering of Judah' refer to in Isaiah 22:8, and how does it relate to the 'house of the forest'?
options: The city's defenses and armory, with the house of the forest being the armory itself
A natural forest protecting the city from enemies
A spiritual protection over Judah
A royal palace made of wood
questions.correctAnswer: The city's defenses and armory, with the house of the forest being the armory itself
questions.explanation: The 'covering of Judah' is understood as the city's military defenses, and the 'house of the forest' was a famous armory or storehouse for weapons in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What critical failure is highlighted in Isaiah 22:11 regarding the city's fortifications and water supply?
options: They neglected to look to the maker who fashioned the water source
They built walls too high to defend
They relied on foreign troops to guard the gates
They stored weapons improperly in the city
questions.correctAnswer: They neglected to look to the maker who fashioned the water source
questions.explanation: Verse 11 condemns the people for failing to acknowledge God, the creator of the water source, showing misplaced trust in human efforts alone.

questions.question: In Isaiah 22:13, the phrase 'Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we shall die' illustrates what type of attitude toward impending disaster?
options: Fatalistic hedonism
Hopeful trust in God
Strategic military planning
Religious repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Fatalistic hedonism
questions.explanation: The verse describes a resignation to fate with indulgence in pleasure, reflecting despair rather than repentance or hope.

questions.question: Who is Shebna as described in Isaiah 22:15-16, and what is his sin according to the text?
options: A treasurer who arrogantly carved a tomb for himself high and secure
A prophet who failed to warn the people
A foreign enemy commander
A wealthy merchant exploiting the poor
questions.correctAnswer: A treasurer who arrogantly carved a tomb for himself high and secure
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 identify Shebna as the treasurer with pride shown in his preparation of a grand tomb, an act of selfish ambition.

questions.question: What is the prophetic consequence that Isaiah pronounces against Shebna in Isaiah 22:17-19?
options: He will be forcibly removed and disgraced in exile
He will be exalted and honored as a leader
He will be killed in battle defending Jerusalem
He will repent and restore the city's defenses
questions.correctAnswer: He will be forcibly removed and disgraced in exile
questions.explanation: The text foretells Shebna's violent removal and shame, emphasizing divine judgment on prideful leadership.

questions.question: Who is Eliakim son of Hilkiah as introduced in Isaiah 22:20-21, and what role is he given?
options: God's servant appointed to replace Shebna as governor
The king of Judah during the siege
A foreign general allied with Jerusalem
A prophet calling for repentance
questions.correctAnswer: God's servant appointed to replace Shebna as governor
questions.explanation: Verses 20-21 describe Eliakim as God's chosen servant, empowered to govern and care for Jerusalem in place of Shebna.

questions.question: What symbolic object is placed on Eliakim's shoulder in Isaiah 22:22, and what is its significance?
options: The key of the house of David, symbolizing authority to open and shut
A sword, symbolizing military power
A crown, symbolizing kingship
A scroll, symbolizing prophetic wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: The key of the house of David, symbolizing authority to open and shut
questions.explanation: The key represents authority given to Eliakim to govern decisively, as expressed in verse 22.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 22:23 use the metaphor of a nail to describe Eliakim’s role, and what does this imply about his stability and importance?
options: He is a secure nail in a sure place, providing firm support
He is a fragile nail that will bend under pressure
He is a rusty nail forgotten by the people
He is a loose nail threatening to fall
questions.correctAnswer: He is a secure nail in a sure place, providing firm support
questions.explanation: The metaphor indicates Eliakim’s firm and dependable leadership, securing the house of his father with stability.

questions.question: What is the ultimate fate of the 'nail fastened in a sure place,' according to Isaiah 22:25?
options: It will be removed, cut down, and fall, indicating loss of leadership
It will remain forever as a symbol of strength
It will be hidden to protect the city
It will be replaced by a stronger nail
questions.correctAnswer: It will be removed, cut down, and fall, indicating loss of leadership
questions.explanation: Verse 25 prophesies the removal of Eliakim’s authority, symbolizing the eventual downfall of the appointed leader.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 22:12-14 depicts a community that responds to divine judgment with sincere mourning and repentance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:12-14 contrasts a call to mourning with the people's response of joy and indulgence, showing rebellious rejection rather than repentance.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 22 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 22 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the 'valley of vision' primarily associated with in Isaiah 22?
options: A place of divine judgment and distress
A site of joyful worship and celebration
A center of political power and peace
A location for prophetic visions of the future
questions.correctAnswer: A place of divine judgment and distress
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:1-5 depicts the valley of vision as a place of trouble, treading down, perplexity, and divine judgment, consistent with God's judgment in other scriptures like Joel 3:14, Ezekiel 7:14, and Revelation 14:19.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 22, what was the cause of the city's distress, considering it was 'not slain with the sword' nor 'dead in battle'?
options: Divine judgment and internal collapse
Foreign military conquest
Famine and plague
Natural disaster
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment and internal collapse
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:2-4 reveals that the city's downfall was due to divine judgment and internal failures rather than a conventional military defeat, paralleling themes in 2 Chronicles 26:16-21 and Jeremiah 5:9.

questions.question: Who are Elam and Kir described as in Isaiah 22:6-7?
options: Nations bearing arms and preparing for battle
Prophets warning the people
Priests interceding for the city
Merchants trading in the valley
questions.correctAnswer: Nations bearing arms and preparing for battle
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:6-7 describes Elam and Kir as armed nations with chariots and horsemen, symbolizing hostile forces, consistent with historical enemies of Israel mentioned in Jeremiah 49:35-38 and Ezekiel 38:5.

questions.question: What criticism does Isaiah 22:11 make about the people’s attitude toward the maker of the city’s defenses?
options: They fortified the city without trusting God
They sought God’s guidance before building
They praised God for the city's protection
They abandoned the city’s walls too quickly
questions.correctAnswer: They fortified the city without trusting God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:11 rebukes the people for focusing on physical defenses without looking to God, echoing Proverbs 21:31 and Psalm 20:7 where trust in God is contrasted with reliance on human strength.

questions.question: What is the attitude of the people in Isaiah 22:13 despite the looming judgment?
options: They indulge in joy and feasting ignoring the danger
They repent and seek mercy from God
They prepare for battle with courage
They mourn and fast in humility
questions.correctAnswer: They indulge in joy and feasting ignoring the danger
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:13 depicts people celebrating and saying 'let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we shall die,' showing a fatalistic and sinful response, which contrasts with calls for repentance in Joel 2:12-13 and Luke 13:3.

questions.question: What consequence does Isaiah 22:14 declare for the iniquity of the people?
options: It will not be purged until they die
It will be forgiven immediately upon repentance
It will be forgotten after a short punishment
It will lead to their exile but eventual restoration
questions.correctAnswer: It will not be purged until they die
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:14 states that the iniquity will remain until death, illustrating the severity of sin’s consequences, consistent with Hebrews 10:26 and Numbers 15:30-31 about persistent sin.

questions.question: Who is Shebna described as in Isaiah 22:15-19, and what is his fate?
options: The treasurer over the house, who will be removed and dishonored
A prophet who will lead the people to repentance
A foreign king who will conquer Jerusalem
A priest who will be honored for his faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: The treasurer over the house, who will be removed and dishonored
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:15-19 identifies Shebna as the treasurer who arrogantly prepares a tomb for himself but is condemned to be removed and humiliated, paralleling God’s judgment on pride in 1 Samuel 2:3 and Daniel 5:23.

questions.question: What office is Eliakim appointed to in Isaiah 22:20-21?
options: He is appointed as the new steward over the house
He is made a high priest of Israel
He is sent as a prophet to the nations
He is crowned king over Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He is appointed as the new steward over the house
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:20-21 describes Eliakim being clothed with the robe and girdle of authority, entrusted with government, indicating his role as steward, a theme consistent with stewardship in Genesis 39:4 and Luke 12:42-44.

questions.question: What does the 'key of the house of David' symbolize when given to Eliakim in Isaiah 22:22?
options: Authority to open and shut, exercising royal power
The possession of secret knowledge
The right to lead the temple worship
The power to punish enemies of the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Authority to open and shut, exercising royal power
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:22 uses the key as a symbol of authority to open and shut, representing control over access and governance, aligning with messianic imagery in Revelation 3:7 and authority granted in Matthew 16:19.

questions.question: How is Eliakim described in terms of stability and leadership in Isaiah 22:23?
options: As a nail fastened in a sure place, a glorious throne
As a wandering shepherd searching for sheep
As a mighty warrior conquering enemies
As a humble servant hidden from view
questions.correctAnswer: As a nail fastened in a sure place, a glorious throne
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:23 portrays Eliakim as a secure and dependable leader, a 'nail' fixed firmly, symbolizing stable governance, consistent with God's promise of firm foundations in Psalm 118:22 and Ephesians 2:20.

questions.question: What is the significance of the vessels hung upon Eliakim in Isaiah 22:24?
options: They represent the responsibilities and glory of his father's house
They symbolize the wealth he will accumulate
They refer to the idols removed from Jerusalem
They depict the offerings given in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They represent the responsibilities and glory of his father's house
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:24 uses the imagery of vessels to symbolize the honor and burdens transferred to Eliakim, paralleling stewardship themes in Exodus 25:29 and 1 Corinthians 4:2 regarding faithful management.

questions.question: What eventual fate is predicted for Eliakim in Isaiah 22:25?
options: He will be removed and fall, as the nail is cut off
He will reign forever as a righteous king
He will be taken to heaven without seeing death
He will become a prophet of the nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will be removed and fall, as the nail is cut off
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:25 forewarns that the secure position of Eliakim will not last, emphasizing the transient nature of human authority, consistent with Ecclesiastes 9:11 and Daniel 2:21 on the rise and fall of leaders.

questions.question: What theological theme is highlighted by the people's failure to look to the 'maker' of the city's defenses in Isaiah 22:11?
options: Human pride and neglect of divine sovereignty
Trust in God's providence over human effort
The necessity of prayer before action
The importance of physical defenses
questions.correctAnswer: Human pride and neglect of divine sovereignty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:11 condemns the people's reliance on physical fortifications without respect for God’s role, illustrating the sin of pride and ignoring God's sovereignty, echoed in Proverbs 16:18 and Jeremiah 17:5.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 22 portray God's role in the judgment and leadership transition?
options: God actively executes judgment and appoints leaders
God passively allows human events to unfold
God only sends prophets to warn without intervention
God punishes foreign nations exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: God actively executes judgment and appoints leaders
questions.explanation: Throughout Isaiah 22, God is depicted as sovereign, bringing judgment (vv. 1-5) and directly appointing Eliakim as steward (vv. 20-22), consistent with divine sovereignty in Romans 13:1 and Daniel 4:17.

questions.question: What eschatological implications can be drawn from the imagery of the 'key of the house of David' in Isaiah 22:22?
options: Messianic authority to open and close the kingdom of God
An end to the Davidic dynasty
The destruction of Jerusalem's temple
The final exile of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Messianic authority to open and close the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 22:22’s key symbolizes authority reminiscent of Christ’s messianic role in Revelation 3:7 and Matthew 16:19, indicating divine control over salvation and the kingdom.
